39435106.review:
BOXVR:
~~~~~~  

Fitness has been a hot topic for as long as I can remember, either keeping bodies in shape or getting them into shape. Let me throw my hat in the ring . . . as a young frog, I used to be super fit, playing soccer at least four times a week (training), plus a full game on the weekend. Then I discovered cooking and fine wines in my mid-twenties, and since then I have accumulated a little bit of fat on my belly. Yeah, I am overweight! This year (2018), I am bringing back my fitness with a daily trip to the gym. Can I fit in some BOXVR as part of my daily routine?

BOXVR is a VR Boxing game where you can take several workout sessions to eliminate as many calories as possible in the comfort of your own home.

First, you’ll need to put your height and weight into the system. Then, you’ll be prompted to go to the main menu where you’ll see a board with your statistics on the left, telling you how many workouts you’ve done, how many calories you’ve burnt, and your percentage of hits.  The rest of the board will give you several other workout options and a tutorial. You can select workouts designed by the developers, try to exercise as long as you can with the survive mode, or train with your own favourite soundtracks. 

I was really excited the designed workouts. There are 17 available to you, choosing between beginner, power, speed, endurance or super endurance. The workout times vary from 5 to 37 minutes. You also have four locations in which to pursue your training: The New York gym, a graveyard, a dark tunnel and a festive winter holiday place. 

The gameplay is absolutely sublime; balls of different colours will come at you at varying speeds, coordinated with music. Some balls will have an arrow, either on a side or underneath, which indicate from which direction you need to hit them, and with which hand.  So get ready to punch, jab and give your best uppercuts! You will have to block incoming objects, as well as squatting and ducking overhead bars.  The other aspect I like about BOXVR is the leader board, which will definitely push you do a good workout in order to grab the top spot, if that’s your motivation. Plus, hitting a ball with more intensity will get you more points.  Keep up your hitting streak and you’ll earn extra multiplier points.  There’s plenty to challenge you and have a great workout!

Personally, I find this game very fluid; I tried several workouts, including the endurance, and I was buggered and dripping with sweat by the end of it! The funny part is that my 65 year-old mother gave it a go and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Then my wife hijacked my computer for a little try.  Fifty minutes later, her checks were bright red - we decided to have a session once a day as part of our daily routine. Yes, BOXVR will give you a seriously good workout! You can even set a daily goal of how many calories you wish to burn.

Graphically, the game is fabulous and the soundtrack is really cool and upbeat; you can train with your own music too.  The developers are going to release more workouts, which will be fab!  One thing I would like to see is more locations; maybe in China, for example, hitting dragon heads.

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

-	Great graphics
-	Great soundtrack
-	Several workout modes (beginner, speed, power, endurance)
-	Train with your own music
-	You’ll burn plenty of calories

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	No achievements or trading cards as yet
-	I’ll love to see more locations with new themes

Want a good workout to burn serious calories? Become a student of Sam and Jonno. I’ll be seeing them daily from now on!

8/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

39430901.review:
[h1]Let us get fit[/h1]

[b]Disclaimer[/b] 
First of all I got this product for free from the developer(s), nevertheless I will review it honestly.

My current room-scale set-up is 1.5x2.5m, and I am not as much affected by motion sickness (anymore).

Furthermore I am no Fitness-Instructor, therefore I cannot professionally judge how effective this method is to get fit.

[b]Overview[/b]
You have several modes you can choose from like Survival (you have a number of life's and try to get a high-score), Fitness-program (as told by the Dev's actually created by real Fitness-Instructors) and your own workout (with your own music).

It is really addictive to play this game but please take the first info-screen you get presented with on start-up seriously and mind your body and not overdo it.

Personally I love the Workout with my own music on which it creates a challenge automatically.

You will not only perform different hits on the target (front, side, upper-cut, block) but you also need to evade obstacles coming up by crouching or tilting your body to the side.

[b]Rating[/b]
9/10 for regular Gamers
10/10 for those who want to prepare for a 220M$ fight :)

[b]The highlights[/b]
[list]
[*] Addictive gameplay
[*] Many modes to choose from
[*] Different Sceneries
[*] Good graphics
[*] Ability to create workout with your playlist
[/list]

[b]The lowlights[/b]
[list]
[*] Not all features implemented yet (Early Access title)
[/list]

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
No! (EarlyAccess)
But you have online Leader-boards

[b]Mods[/b]
No! (EarlyAccess)

[b]Motion Sickness[/b]
Since you are standing in one spot it will not cause any nausea

[b]Microtransactions/DLC[/b]
No! (EarlyAccess)

[b]Summary[/b]
As I tested this one the first time I could barely stop.
!!Please do yourself the favour and stop once you feel exhausted, as advised.!!

It is fun to do this kind of workout for short sessions a day, listening to your favourite music while moving your body is addictive. I am looking forward to how this game develops during the course of the Early Access but it feels like a complete experience already.

So if you would like to do something similar to a real-workout this might be the game for you and absolutely worth the price.

I might update this review after I got more experience playing it, so stay tuned.

I'm into rhythm games (already own Audioshield and Holodance, and used to play DDR at the arcades), but I specifically bought BoxVR for the workout aspect, which it delivers on.

Holodance is my go-to rhythm game, but the difference is that in Holodance (and Audioshield) you "catch" notes, whereas in BoxVR, you need to actively "hit" them.

Overall very polished, and even though it still needs some improvement, like not just having circles come at you for different types of hits (left hooks and right hooks are almost identical, for example; blocks aren't differentiated well enough from regular hits) but I didn't have any problem with unregistered hits, which I think has since been fixed from just before (or maybe just after) I bought it.

39196386.review:
Given that this product is still early access, BoxVR makes it VERY obvious that the game is incompleted at this time. Although it's a great work out when you're in the rhythm,however the faulty hit registration, awkward screen centering, off-beat music and the lack of variety in music really makes it frustrating to want to come back..

The hit registration is especially bad, as there are no indicators as to where the punch can be drawn to. 

The forced left/right stance change is annoying as well and can really mess up your rhythm and even hurt yourself if you're not used to moving/dodging on your opposite stance.

Overall, I don't think this product is worth the price tag yet. Once they figure out how to synchronise the music properly and fix their hit registration, along with a greater variety of music, I think I might give this a 5/5.. for now, 2/5

38676527.review:
I wish there was a "lukewarm" option because I don't strongly dislike this game, but in the current state I certainly can't say I like it. I want to say first up that spent some time on the forums and I think the devs are top notch. I have little doubt that this game will be worth purchasing down the road because the devs seem to be very active in the community and I think they're really working hard to make the game better. 

That said, in the current form I find this game a lot more frustrating than fun. The biggest reason is that the hit detection is extremely poor in my experience. While it's possible that there's some issue with my setup (3 sensor Rift), I've had no issues with any other games. Maybe I just suck, but it's very difficult to tell what the source of the issue is because there is no feedback to allow you to improve. I see that this is listed as one of the dev goals; if properly implemented that could go a long way in improving the game. 

It still stands that right now, a frustrating number of jab and cross orbs simply go right through your boxing glove. After a bunch of experimentation I found that using slow, swiping gestures resulted in the best game performance, but it doesn't result in much of a workout and it also doesn't feel very satisfying. Oddly I had no problems with the uppercuts or hooks -when I missed I felt like it was my own fault. The dodge and duck mechanics go totally the other way, being so absurdly forgiving that a slight dip of a few inches is enough to clear the obstacle. 

So basically I can either try to punch hard and fast and have 80% of the orbs go right through my gloves, or do easy swipes and lazy dodges and get a pretty good score. 

The other problem I have with the game isn't really early access related, and may be more of a long term problem. Compared to other workout games I've played (thinking mainly of Soundboxing and Holopoint here), BoxVR is just kind of boring. While the variety of punch types is awesome and the uppercuts and hooks feel great, still the punches all land at the same place and other than changing your stance a few times during a song and doing a few very forgiving squats you're not really moving around much. Also, compared to other rhythm VR games, even the fastest workout speeds are pretty slow.  

The end result to me is that it feels like you're doing a somewhat enjoyable but bland workout while wearing a headset. Soundboxing (with a decent beatmap) is a total blast of a game which just incidentally results in an amazing workout – you're using the whole width and height of your room and punching at a frantic rate. Holopoint as well feels so much more dynamic than just standing in the center of your room looking forward, punching at the same height and doing the odd half-assed squat. 

Pros: Great devs - Punch types and inclusion of dodges add variety 

Cons: Poor hit detection – Little spatial movement – Bland workouts – Little musical variety – Comparatively ineffective workout – Inaccurate calorie counter

Summary – If this was the only VR workout game in existence, I would recommend it. As it is, there are multiple options that are better workouts, more fun and cheaper.

38495259.review:
BoxVR has quickly become my favorite VR "game". 

I've put "game" in quotes, because BoxVR is really a VR workout, and not a "game". While there are game-like aspects (e.g. high score list, etc.), it's emphasis is on giving you a great cardio workout. And it does that.

But, that's not to say that it isn't fun. It is fun. There is something incredibly satisfying about hitting the targets and seeing them burst into a spray of neon color. Getting into a good rhythm and powering my way through the routines gives me an incredible rush of positive energy.

As for the quality of the workout, you'll find that you get out of it what you put in. Some knowledge of actual boxing (or martial arts) is probably required to really enjoy this and get the most out of it. You don't need to be Sugar Ray Leonard, but If you don't already know how to throw a proper punch, BoxVR may not appeal to you. As of this writing, BoxVR doesn't teach you how to box or throw  punches. The short tutorial is helpful, but it won't serve to teach a complete beginner.

One criticism of the current state of BoxVR is that the "calorie" counter is ... aspirational, at best. By which I mean that if you put 100% effort and proper form and power into each punch, then the calories displayed in the game may be somewhat accurate. It's possible, however, to do the routines "lightly" and simply touch the targets and still get points. In that case, you will not be burning anywhere near the number of calories displayed. The displayed calories are therefore misleading, and I wish the developers would be even more clear that the calorie count is a rough estimate of an optimal workout and not an accurate measure of what you personally are achieving in a given workout (they do have a blanket statement to that effect in the fine print at the start of the game).

As I write this, BoxVR is still in early access, and there are regular updates coming from the developers as they add new features and make changes. I've found a few hiccups in the game: some odd behavior and a glitch here and there. That said, the developers appear (at the time of this writing) to be very responsive and seem to care about making their product better.

If you have some experience with boxing (or cardio boxing, or martial arts, or what have you) and are looking for a fun workout, then you could do far worse that give BoxVR at try.

37825923.review:
I will say, in this game's favour, it has a LOT of potential. In barely 20 minutes of play I could really feel the strain it put on my chest. I get a sense that the people behind it know what they are doing. Although the calorie counter seems a little... optimistic? Put another way, if I were really burning that many calories I'd have the BMI of a stick insect. (...wistful sigh)

Also, I am an idiot, so take my feedback with a pinch of salt... this is an Early Access title so there's scope for change, and there's lots of positive reviews as well... etc etc.

That said, out of the box this game breaks one of the most simple rules of game development: don't needlessly frustrate the user!!

The premise is to exercise by hitting orbs in particular fashion, but the gameplay is very unrewarding because unless you do precisely what the game wants you to, the orbs phase right through your fists... And what it wants isn't clear! The biggest offenders were hitting the orbs from the sides. Uppercuts seem to work fairly well. 

This is game development 101!!! If I hit the orb... I HIT THE ORB!! Argh. By all means deduct points, or tell me my technique is wrong/isn't hard enough/etc etc... but REGISTER that I hit the orb and give me the feedback through the controller!! Don't phase it through my angry, flailing limbs like I became a ghost for 200 milliseconds. Straight punches work perfectly for instance, even if you lazily extend your fist and wait for the orb to blithely plow into it.

I survived about 20 minutes, with a break in between to test Audioshield and confirm that yes, that is way, WAY better for a workout and a million times less frustrating, and then take my arm weights off to see if them slowing down my punches was causing the hits not to count. But it wasn't! Yep... if you're trying to be like Piccolo from Dragonball Z training with hundreds of pounds of weights on your body, you can keep on doing what you're doing, it isn't affecting your gameplay here, it seems.

I varied the speed, to no avail. I varied the timing, to no avail. I tried adjusting the glove position relative to my controllers to ensure I really hit the orbs squarely on the side (THAT is a cool feature, I like that) but to no avail. Bewildered, I began to question my sanity. I even tried looking at videos of blokes punching things to make sure I even understood what a proper hook was. Do I just not know how to punch stuff in the side? Should I have punched more stuff in the past? Fought more people throughout life? Maybe I could've tried to be angrier as a teenager, I don't know.

And then, as I reuminated over my newfound relatively nonviolent regrets of the past, I found the answer. The terrible, awful answer. It seems I have more success "slapping" the orbs. 

That's right... punch, duck, punch, uppercut, UNMANLY EFFEMINATE SLAPPING, punch, duck, punch... 

If I didn't feel silly before, I certainly did when I realised that was the only way to *partially* increase the chances of scoring a hit. I mean I don't mind if they do want me to slap dat but they should've said so, don't make it sound all fighty and awesome.

In short: If you're used to Audioshield, this is not for you. It's VERY frustrating to play. Stick with Audioshield, pick an aggressive song on Elite difficulty, and try not to die by the end of it. If you've never played Audioshield and want to get reaaaally good at slapping things, this game is right up your street.

37237401.review:
For some VR is a means of improving social contact. Others want to feel immersed. Pretend to be a war hero. A cyber ninja. For some it's about weight loss.

Weight loss? Yes, weight loss. See: During VR gameplay you move your body a lot. Wether it's steps or other physical movements, you tend to burn a lot of calories. There is even a case of someone losing more than 50 pounds playing a VR game. So losing weight and VR comes hand-in-hand. But of course these games aren't really focused on cardio.

That's where BOXVR comes in. 

Unlike other games, this game (well, fitness program might be a better fit) has been made with real fitness instructors aboard the advisory train. It's aim? Get your cardio going and shed some weight while you're at it.

The gameplay is simple. You punch, dodge and block incoming balls to the beat of your own music. 

You hit them straight forward, you do uppercuts and sidejabs. Sometimes you'll have to put your arms up to dodge, sometimes you'll be squatting. It's very simple to pick-up-and-play. But the thing is: You're continously moving. The great thing about BOXVR is that you actually have to throw in some weight with your punches. You don't just touch the balls, no. You need to actually exercise and punch. The squats add to the workout so by the end of a session your whole body will have had some work. 

Incoming projectiles are generated based on your own music. That's right, you can load-up your own music straight into the game and it'll use it to custom-tailor a workout to the beats of your own music. You can choose from 3 difficulties: Easy, Medium and Hard. I, personally, recommend hard. It'll keep you moving continously and after 30 minutes I definitely felt a little bit sore in my arms and I was sweating like crazy. A sweatband comes highly recommended. You don't want your foam to soak up your sweet due to hygienic reasons. 

During a workout the game gives you a score (it's really fun trying to beat your own scores!), the amount of calories burned, time left and your current hit streak. It's simplistic yet: this game requires nothing more than the basic information. Calories burned are taken from calculations based on your height and weight which you input into the game. I kinda feel like the game overshoots a little with how many calories you burn, but that's understandable considering you don't need measurement hardware for the game to function. 

Of course, with the game still being in Early Access, there are some bugs here 'n there. For example: I think the calories-burned tracker kinda overshoots a little bit. Sometimes the game won't track burned calories in songs you've loaded in. Everything else functions perfectly. All the punch hits are detected instantly and flawlessly. The graphics are alright, the motions are great and fluid. The UI easy to use. 

All in all: I don't see BOXVR as a game. I see it more as a cardio workout. Want to lose some weight? Go for it. Want to stay in shape/keep your cardio up? Go for it!

I know I'll be throwing that gym membership out the window for sure. ;)

The game will either do left stance or right stance (boxing stances) and you'll jab, hook, upppercut, block, duck down, or weave.  Timing is everything and combos of ducking while blocking to immediately uppercut to another duck ups the intensity.  The three environments are nothing special and the graphics are simple.  But it gets the job done.  This is a VR workout game done to be as fun/immersive as possible with tunes, not a music rhtyhm game in the traditional sense.

It wowed me at the time and I was mega excited about it but I've now had the game a month so thought an updated review would be appropriate. Well first off I have to say this game has plenty of staying power. I had bought this alongside several other fitness type games to get me into shape and this, far and away is the most addictive and compelling. I have now put in 25 hours and haven't missed a day's training since I bought it, averaging 45 minutes a night. My fitness has hugely improved, I have a flat stomach now and I've even started doing push ups and pull ups after workouts as it's got me fired up to train! The gameplay is simple but compelliing, and works the whole body. Power workouts give you lots of squats and leg work, Speed workouts are great fun allowing you throw dozens up fast combinations and really get into a fitness zone training like you're Floyd Mayweather. Endurance mixes the two styles and extends the workouts to between 20 and 35 minutes. Some of the workouts are short but it literally takes about 10 seconds to transition from the end of one workout to starting a new one so don't avoid them, and they are timed well giving you a chance to wipe the sweat from your headset before you dive into the next one. In all I one hundred percent recommend this game!

8 out of 10

I'm really keen on using VR for fitness and BOXVR is a total winner for me. I'm really enjoying the different excercises, It's sort of like Audioshield with punching. BOXVR has different routines to support speed, power, and endurance. During a session it includes breaks and swapping stances. And each segment of the session is a different sequence of punches and dodging. It feels really well balanced.

The game feels really good already and there's loads of untapped scope for adding more variety to the exercises, the greyed out sections shows this is already planned on the roadmap.

My Steam library is packed with a number of high intensity VR games, but they aren't specifically designed for fitness training but they get you tired pretty quickly. BOXVR is better than those, the pacing keeps you working hard but not to exhaustion.

40554506.review:
EDIT:
OK, a little background first. I am overweight because I hate exercise. 101 KG (or 220 pounds, somewhere in there) and about 177 CM or 5'10. For years I have looked for an exercise I could stick with and I never found one. Since I was a kid I always thought maybe VR would be my solution. I thought only then I could get into it. You know what? I was right. In the last two or three weeks I have put 9 hours, roughly, into this game. I love this game so much I bought every similar game I could find: Soundboxing, Holodance, Thrill of the Fight, Gorn, etc. They're all great games but I pretty much spend all my time in BoxVR.

Why? I'm so glad you asked!
First of all, the game is brightly colored and has excellent graphics that fit the aesthetic and give you a sense of life and vitality that our real world gyms with their stagnant colors and ugly designs cannot give you. You can choose from 4 arenas, and the devs have confirmed in the forums (where they post and answer virtually any questions EVERY DAMN DAY) that more arenas, custom workouts, and content is coming. A public beta just went out yesterday that made it so now when you load your MP3s into the game to generate workouts automatically (a feature which works surprisingly well and is my go-to mode of play), you can save a playlist. A small but necessary QoL enhancement. They post updates just about every week!

Another thing: When I first started I posted some comments on the forums saying "Sometimes during certain songs the beats come at you so fast that it's physically impossible to hit them". Well, that may be true for songs with a super high BPM, but after just a few weeks of using the program just about every day, I feel embarrassed for ever expressing that sentiment. You get good QUICK! And it feels so rewarding toget a huge combo of like 200 or 300 or a perfect song on Hard mode.

Make sure you use proper form for your squats, dodges, and the different kinds of punches to maximize your workout and avoid straining yourself unnecessarily!

SUMMARY: If you have VR this is literally the only program you need to make it worth your investment. No joke. Buy this game.


ORIGINAL REVIEW: If you have any VR setup for PC, you must get this game. It comes with preloaded exercises but more importantly, you can upload your own MP3 files and it'll analyze them and create an exercise routine based on the song. I HAVE NEVER HAD MORE FUN EXERCISING OR EVEN PLAYING VIDEO GAMES OF ANY KIND IN RECENT MEMORY. Get this game, buy it full price, support the devs.

I don't normally review products or games, but BoxVR is worth the time. 

I personally am not a fan of working out mainly because, for me, running on a tred or track is super boring. My dislike for running got so bad that I actually got out from the military because I didn't like my entire career success or failure resting on how fast I could run. After repeated overseas deployments my run got slower and slower and my stress before testing and working out higher and higher. After I got out I was so happy to not have that stress I just didn't do anything. Bottom line: I don't like cardio.

That was until BoxVR. I bought it on a whim after seeing an auto-play video ad on some site (maybe I shouldn't mention that because that style of advertising is super annoying) The tutorials got me hooked and the pre-made workouts kept me coming back for more. The work out with your own music feature is the iceing on the cake. The song profiling technology seems to work very well with the techno-classical music I have tried it with. 

Unlike every other workout I have expericed prior to this, the time just zooms by. An intense (by my standards anyway) 15-30 minute workout seems to be over before it starts. 

Pros:
- Pre-built workouts seem well timed and the music pretty good
- The audio profiling tech seems to produce well sync'd workouts

Suggestions
- If the technology supports it, it would be nice to have a feeback summary on if you are performing the various punches with the right "form"
- More statistics on as much as possible would be awesome

Thanks for a great product!

Wegen solcher Spiele liebe ich VR. Sehr schweißtreibend, sehr motivierend und trotz Early Access Status schon ein ordentlicher Funktionsumfang.

Das Spiel eignet sich für Spieler, die entweder Audio-Games à la Guitar Hero oder Audioshield mögen oder nach einer Möglichkeit suchen, sich vollkommen auszupowern. 

Das Spielprinzip ist simpel: Man schlägt, untermalt und im Takt von Musik, nach farbigen Bällen und kombiniert dies mit Bewegungen, beispielsweise Squats. Akkurate Schläge und Bewegungen führen zu einer höheren Punktzahl. 

Das Spiel bietet unterschiedliche Modi, wie vorgefertigte Workouts, Endlosspiel sowie Workouts zu eigener, via MP3 eingespielter, Musik. 

Einziger Kritikpunkt: Trotz vermeintlich (vielleicht liegt es auch an meiner Schlagtechnik?!) korrekter Schläge werden die Bälle nicht immer korrekt getroffen, insbesondere bei Bällen von der Seite. 

Ansonsten kann ich das Spiel aber auch schon im jetzigen Stadium empfehlen und freue mich auf weitere Neuerungen!

11/10. Would love to feel tired and sweaty again after a good workout!

The actual review:
=============
Love, love, love this game! I am REALLY impressed at the features and implementations that FitXR has added. My main thing that I like is how responsive the developers are to the community. Have a feature request, let the developers know on the appropriate thread. Have a bug that you've noticed (keeping in mind that this game is in early access), tell the developers! At the time of writing, the developer response time is also VERY quick. I like how the community's ideas, problems, and opinions are being taken into account unlike a very good portion of all other games.

All in all, this is THE GAME to play if you want to lose pounds, feel great, and enjoy listening to your own music. I haven't tried out any other modes than the training mode, but I like how they are using REAL fitness coaches' input for the other modes. THIS IS WHAT VR WAS MADE FOR!!!

39892979.review:
I very much reccommend this game for both workouts, and if you like an active rythm game to music you can choose. I use it for an added cardio workout to my usual workout routine, and it's the most enjoyable way to do that!

My reccommendations would be to:
````````````````````````````````````````````````````
 - Make your own music tracks have more intricate punching patterns, as I feel it's the same thing no matter the song chosen, and is too easy even on the chosen hard difficulty. This makes me just play the harder pre-made workouts and listen to my own music on the side so I can get the intesity of the workout with my own music.

 - Let you move your middle position of the play area where you want, like the games that get you to move by dragging yourself around. I have the smallest possible room-scale area and the optimal punching space is a little too far forward to my liking, but this is a tiny detail at best.

 - Add more genres of ingame music workouts. There's only house and ONE "rock" option that still sounds like a techno song, so there's not much variety of ingame music, and as I said when you choose your music it's too easy, so that gets rid of the difficulty of the pre-made workouts that have the one genre of music.

THAT'S IT, that's the only 3 things I myself have noticed I don't like 100% about it, but those are only VERY tiny annoyances at best, and do not hinder my playing experience enough to care. I really can't think of any serious problems with the game as it covers anything you'd want in a game like. this. Your own music workouts, PERFECT hand positioning to your liking, variety of workouts on a large scale of intensity, and a decent variety of play areas/levels that keeps growing.

Final note is that I love how this has been updated frequently and has VERY much improved since I first got BOX VR. So much has improved.

As someone who is HUGE on VR stuff I highly reccommend this game/workout tool.

Solid 8/10.

I gotta say, I was pretty skeptical about this when I first saw it. "A fun looking VR game, that gives you a workout? Impossible! Working out can't be fun, and there is no way you can effectively do it in a video game!" Thats what I thought before I tried it out, and let me tell you, I couldn't have been more wrong. 

I just got done playing my first half hour in this game, and I jumped straight into the harder workouts thinking it would be super easy, and man was I wrong. I worked up a sweat in about 10 minutes, and I loved it. I've never had a VR game actually make me sweat like that, or wear me out so quickly. I feel like I just got back from the gym after just 30 minutes. Not only that, but it is so much freaking fun. 

The included music pumps you up, but if that isn't for you, you have the ability to play your own music which the game will build a workout from. It also cheers you on in a sense by giving you encourageing messages when you hit a hard combo. 

If you are at all skeptical about this game like I was, do yourself a huge favor and buy it. It is worth every penny.

39662073.review:
So far I have to give this thumbs up.  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vhdArjgJTd4
The techniques are very simple, the music is good and when combined they make for a good workout and that is exactly what this is, there is no game, no other distraction just a workout (there is a score leader board too).

== RECOMMENDATIONS ==
- Profiles.
- Warm-Up.
- Make more use of high & low orbs (watch my review).
- Make more effort to accurately track calories (check intensity).
- Sometimes positive message get in the way!  Adjust or replace with audio.
- Change positive messages to audio congrats? DLC perhaps Language specific.
- Option for bigger bubbles for less accurate people.
- More exercises (harder) without knee bending (for those with poor knees).
- Challenge mode, where your score is compared to the #1 on leaderboard.
- For longer exercises a sweat break, these headset get hot and sweat stings!
- Extra Challenge where there are wider punching zones..step left to get the ones on left etc...
- When in rest (mid workout) show how long there is to rest...time for sweatbreak or water?
- Knee to hand movement?
- Use thumbstick buttons for main menu...stop accidental clicks.


== PRO ==
- Looks good.
- Audio is Good.
- Design is Good.
- Workouts are fun and enough to make you sweat (beginner’s mode v.easy).
- Caters for all fitness levels.
- You can play your own music.
- Tracks data quite well, lots of info available...Accuracy, score, calories, # of workouts.
- Works one side of body then the other side.

== CON ==
- No way to have profiles, kind of catered for just 1 player.
- Not many workouts.
- Playing own audio does not match the rhythm.
- Potential for injury as very active (not really a con just a FYI).
- The combos are sometimes unnatural - L.Jab/L.cross followed by a L.Uppercut does not flow well.
- I feel that none of the workouts have really utilised the potential this game has...yet
- No Steam workshop (for workout combos for a specific song).
- Calories are not accurate.


== FULL REVIEW ==
There is a small number of pre-designed workouts (approx. 10-12) and they progress in speed and required effort pretty well.

In each workout there are colour coded floating orbs and you will perform, jabs, uppercuts, crosses and also have to squat and avoid horizontal bars.

There are also a number of locations; the main gym is my personal choice but there is a Christmas themed version too which plays slightly diff with actual presents occasionally coming at you (no idea how to deal with those).

The game tracks quite a bit of information, calories burnt (not sure if accurate) sessions completed and your score; there is a leader board of highest scores.  It is not clear atm what constitutes a max score, perhaps a combination of power/effort per punch and accuracy?

You do need good balance for this game, the speed and effort put in can at times throw you off your footing and with a headset on it makes it a little harder to recalibrate yourself.

Sometimes I do feel the workouts are in-time to music, sometimes they are not, or are just off.  Playing with your own music though the game does not match the beat, which is a bit of a shame and a missed opportunity IMHO (there are other similar games which do).

The only real gripes I have with the game are that some combinations don't feel right or natural. Left jab followed by a left uppercut causes a strange sensation in my arm; there is a break of natural flow when that happens.  It is as though someone sat at a PC and just selected a punch from a list of available punches without really trying it out first.

Finally my only other concern is...will it get repetitive? With such a small number of exercises available I feel that things will become mundane too quickly.  Steam workshop would be the obvious solution (although audio might hinder this/could upload a workout for `x` song and you have to provide the song I guess) 

Is worth the money, my gut instinct is that it will be, only time will tell.
